context: SID 6581/8580 Sound Interface Device - Programming Guide

splits.reason: Title, document header and sources — metadata (non-technical)

splits.name: overview_and_capabilities
splits.description: High-level overview of the SID chip (designer, platforms) and capabilities: 3 voices, 4 waveforms, 16-bit frequency, 12-bit pulse width, ADSR envelopes, ring modulation, sync, 4-bit master volume, multi-mode filter, ADC paddle inputs, external audio input.

references.topic: register base address and mirror range

splits.name: chip_variants_6581_8580
splits.description: Comparison of MOS 6581 vs MOS 8580: production years, process (NMOS vs HMOS-II), supply voltages, filter capacitor values, tonal differences, DC offset, digi playback quirk on 6581 and hardware mod for 8580, and 6581 sub-revisions R1/R2/R3/R4AR.

references.topic: 4-bit digi playback differences and resistor mod

splits.name: complete_register_map_intro
splits.description: SID register base address $D400 (54272), mirror range $D400-$D7FF (32-byte mirror), voice register offsets (Voice1 $D400-$D406, Voice2 $D407-$D40D, Voice3 $D40E-$D414), and note that registers $D400-$D418 are write-only except $D419-$D41C.

splits.name: voice1_registers
splits.description: Voice 1 registers $D400-$D406: $D400 Frequency low byte, $D401 Frequency high byte (16-bit frequency, PAL/NTSC clocks and Fout calculation), $D402/$D403 Pulse Width (12-bit, PW% and special values), $D404 Control bits (waveform selects, TEST, RING MOD, SYNC, GATE), $D405 Attack/Decay (nibbles), $D406 Sustain/Release (nibbles). Notes on combined waveforms and LFSR lockup.

references.topic: triangle waveform behavior and ring mod
ADSR rates and usage with GATE

splits.name: voice2_registers
splits.description: Voice 2 registers $D407-$D40D: Frequency low/high ($D407/$D408), Pulse Width low/high ($D409/$D40A), Control register $D40B (bit 2 RING MOD modulates with Voice 1, bit 1 SYNC syncs with Voice 1; other bits same as Voice 1), $D40C Attack/Decay, $D40D Sustain/Release.

references.topic: voice pairing for SYNC and RING MOD

splits.name: voice3_registers
splits.description: Voice 3 registers $D40E-$D414: Frequency low/high ($D40E/$D40F), Pulse Width low/high ($D410/$D411), Control register $D412 (bit 2 RING MOD modulates with Voice 2, bit 1 SYNC syncs with Voice 2), $D413 Attack/Decay, $D414 Sustain/Release. Voice 3 can be read out for modulation at $D41B/$D41C.

splits.name: filter_registers_and_modes_overview
splits.description: Filter registers $D415-$D418: $D415 Filter cutoff low 3 bits, $D416 Filter cutoff high 8 bits (11-bit cutoff 0-2047, mapping differs 6581 vs 8580), $D417 Resonance (bits 7-4), external input route (bit 3) and voice routing bits (bits 0-2), $D418 Filter mode bits (mute voice 3 bit 7, HP bit6, BP bit5, LP bit4) and master volume (bits 3-0). Explains filter mode combinations and approximate cutoff ranges for 6581/8580.

references.topic: EXT IN pin and external audio routing

splits.name: read_only_registers
splits.description: Readable SID registers $D419-$D41C: $D419 Paddle X (8-bit analog value), $D41A Paddle Y, $D41B Voice 3 oscillator output (upper 8 bits of waveform; saw: ramp 0-255, triangle: up/down, pulse: 0/255, noise: random), $D41C Voice 3 envelope output (ADSR envelope 0-255). Updated timing notes and typical usage for modulation.

references.topic: which registers are read-only vs write-only

splits.name: adsr_overview
splits.description: ADSR envelope operation per voice: Attack (rise to peak), Decay (fall to Sustain level), Sustain (level while GATE=1), Release (fall to 0 when GATE=0). Notes on retrigger behavior. Includes timing table mapping ADSR nibble values (0-15) to approximate Attack/Decay/Release times and comments on PAL/NTSC variations and internal non-linear counters.

splits.name: adsr_bug
splits.description: Description of the SID ADSR bug: internal rate counter can delay Attack when triggered during Release due to LFSR-based rate counter. Workarounds include setting GATE=0 then GATE=1 or 'hard restart' techniques to preset envelope state before retriggering.

references.topic: initialization/hard restart techniques in player code

splits.name: waveforms_section_header
splits.description: Section header introducing SID waveforms: triangle, sawtooth, pulse/rectangle, noise, and combinations.
splits.reason: audit: No technical details—only a high-level pointer/TOC to other SID waveform chunks.

splits.name: waveforms_triangle
splits.description: Triangle waveform: linear up/down ramp, contains only odd harmonics with amplitudes proportional to 1/(n^2), produces soft flute-like tone, can be ring-modulated (requires TRIANGLE bit), used for smooth modulation when used as LFO.

references.topic: use triangle on Voice 3 for smooth LFO

splits.name: waveforms_sawtooth
splits.description: Sawtooth waveform: linear rise then sharp drop, contains all harmonics with amplitudes proportional to 1/n, bright/brassy tone ideal for strings, brass, pads, high harmonic content.

references.topic: select sawtooth via control register bit
combining sawtooth with triangle/pulse for timbral variation

splits.name: waveforms_pulse_rectangle
splits.description: Pulse/Rectangle waveform: variable duty cycle (12-bit PWn), at 50% PWn=2048 produces square wave (only odd harmonics), other duty cycles include even harmonics, PWM produces chorus-like effect, PWM examples and recommended use.

references.topic: patch examples using PWM (Piano, Synth Lead)

splits.name: waveforms_noise
splits.description: Noise waveform: pseudo-random noise via 23-bit LFSR, LFSR shift rate controlled by frequency register (higher frequency = brighter noise), used for percussion/effects. Warning: selecting noise with other waveforms can lock LFSR; fix by writing TEST then desired waveform.

references.topic: using filtered noise for hand clap

splits.name: combined_waveforms
splits.description: Combined waveforms: multiple waveform bits produce a logical AND of waveforms. On 6581 combined waveforms produce unique timbres; on 8580 they are quieter or silent. Common combos: Triangle+Saw ($30), Triangle+Pulse ($50), Saw+Pulse ($60). Avoid combining Noise with others (locks LFSR).

references.topic: different combined waveform behavior on 6581 vs 8580

splits.name: frequency_section_header
splits.description: Section header: Frequency reference for SID oscillators and formula introduction.

references.topic: formula for converting Fn to Fout

splits.name: frequency_calculation
splits.description: Frequency formula: Fout = (Fn * Fclk) / 16777216 where Fn is 16-bit frequency register (0-65535). PAL Fclk=985248 Hz, NTSC Fclk=1022727 Hz. Inverse formula and examples (PAL/NTSC minimum/maximum frequencies).

references.topic: PAL Fn table and A4=440Hz example

splits.name: note_frequency_table_pal
splits.description: Approximate 16-bit SID frequency register values (PAL clock 985248 Hz) for notes C..B across octaves 0-7. Includes tuning note A4 = 440 Hz => Fn = $1CC8 and note on calculating precise Fn.

references.topic: formula used to compute table values

splits.name: note_frequency_table_ntsc
splits.description: Approximate 16-bit SID frequency register values (NTSC clock 1022727 Hz) for notes C..B across octaves 0-7. Use for NTSC machines; values differ slightly from PAL.

references.topic: NTSC clock differences in Fn calculation

splits.name: filter_overview
splits.description: Overview: single multi-mode resonant filter shared by all three voices and external input. Voices can be routed individually via $D417 bits 0-2; voices not routed bypass the filter and go directly to the mixer.

splits.name: filter_modes
splits.description: Filter modes described: Low-pass (LP, bit4 $D418), Band-pass (BP, bit5), High-pass (HP, bit6). Effects on tone and combined mode behaviors: LP+HP (notch), LP+BP, HP+BP, LP+BP+HP (all-pass/phase shift).

references.topic: how cutoff value affects these modes

splits.name: filter_cutoff_frequency
splits.description: Cutoff frequency is 11-bit value across $D415 (low 3 bits) and $D416 (high 8 bits). CutoffValue = (HighByte << 3) | (LowByte & 0x07). Mapping differs by chip: 6581 non-linear ~200Hz–12kHz and temperature dependent; 8580 more linear ~30Hz–12kHz.

references.topic: differences in cutoff mapping between revisions

splits.name: resonance_control
splits.description: Resonance bits 7-4 of $D417 (0-15). Resonance emphasizes frequencies at cutoff; high values create pronounced peaks and on 6581 can self-oscillate (used as a crude fourth oscillator); 8580 less prone to self-oscillation.

splits.name: synchronization
splits.description: Oscillator synchronization forces one voice's accumulator to reset every cycle of the synchronizing voice producing complex harmonics. Hard-wired pairings: Voice1 syncs to Voice3 (bit1 $D404), Voice2 -> Voice1 (bit1 $D40B), Voice3 -> Voice2 (bit1 $D412). Example 'mosquito' effect and sweeping technique described.

references.topic: SYNC bit location in control register
related modulation techniques for complex timbres

splits.name: ring_modulation
splits.description: Ring modulation replaces a voice's triangle output with product of that triangle and the modulating voice oscillator, creating sum/difference frequencies (non-harmonic metallic timbres). Pairings: Voice1 mod by Voice3 (bit2 $D404), Voice2 by Voice1 (bit2 $D40B), Voice3 by Voice2 (bit2 $D412). Triangle bit must be set on modulated voice; modulator must run but needn't be gated.

references.topic: triangle waveform is required for ring mod

splits.name: voice3_modulation_intro
splits.description: Voice 3 can be muted (bit7 $D418) while still providing oscillator/envelope readouts at $D41B/$D41C, allowing it to serve as a dedicated modulation source (LFO) without audible output.

splits.name: vibrato_technique
splits.description: Vibrato via Voice 3 oscillator read ($D41B): set Voice3 low frequency (4-7Hz), triangle waveform, mute Voice3 (bit7 $D418), read $D41B each frame and add a scaled value to target voice's frequency registers to produce pitch oscillation. Depth controlled by scaling/division.

references.topic: how added modulation affects Fn and Fout

splits.name: tremolo_technique
splits.description: Tremolo (amplitude modulation) using Voice 3: configure Voice3 as low-frequency triangle, read $D41B and use to modify master volume or target voice's sustain level to vary amplitude over time.

references.topic: similar setup but modulates frequency vs amplitude

splits.name: filter_sweeps
splits.description: Using Voice3 to modulate filter cutoff ($D415/$D416): set Voice3 as LFO, read $D41B and add/write scaled values to cutoff registers to perform automatic sweeps (wah-wah). Waveform selection (triangle, sawtooth, pulse, noise) affects sweep shape.

references.topic: using Voice3 as an LFO for different parameters

splits.name: programming_section_header
splits.description: Section header introducing SID programming techniques and example code snippets in 6502 assembly.

splits.name: programming_initialization
splits.description: Initialization example: clear SID registers ($D400..), set master volume ($D418) to desired value. Example code clearing 24 registers and setting volume to maximum.

references.topic: SID base address $D400 and mirror behavior

splits.name: playing_a_simple_note
splits.description: Assembly example to play a simple note on Voice 1: set ADSR ($D405/$D406), write frequency bytes ($D400/$D401) for A4=$1CC8 (PAL), select waveform and GATE ($D404), then later clear GATE to start release.

references.topic: ADSR setup for the note example
frequency register values used in example

splits.name: pwm_technique
splits.description: Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) technique: initialize PW to 50% ($D402/$D403 = $0800), select pulse waveform + gate ($D404), and increment PW each frame (example loop using $D402/$D403). Suggestion: use 16-bit counter and delta for smoother PWM.

references.topic: role of pulse width in timbre
timing PWM updates with raster or timer

splits.name: music_engine_structure
splits.description: Example music engine structure (KickAssembler syntax): program counter, frequency table of 16-bit values, initialization clearing SID and setting volume/ADSR, play routine called per frame that reads frequency table, writes $D400/$D401, gates voice, checks end marker and loops. Includes pseudocode for note advancement.

references.topic: calling play per frame via raster IRQ

splits.name: raster_synchronized_playback
splits.description: Tie music playback to VIC-II raster interrupt for consistent timing: sample code to set IRQ vector at $0314/$0315, configure rasterline ($D012/$D011), enable raster IRQ ($D01A), IRQ handler acknowledges ($D019) and calls play routine, then jp to KERNAL IRQ handler. Typical rates: 50Hz PAL / 60Hz NTSC; alternative timers suggested for higher resolution.

splits.name: sound_effects_section_header
splits.description: Header introducing several sound-effect code examples: laser/zap, explosion, drum kick, hand clap.

splits.name: sound_effect_laser
splits.description: Laser/Zap example: ADSR settings A=0 D=15, S/R low, start with high frequency ($D401), select sawtooth or noise+gate ($D404 = $81 for noise laser), sweep frequency down each frame by decrementing $D401.

splits.name: sound_effect_explosion
splits.description: Explosion example: short ADSR (A=0,D=0; S=15,R=9), low frequency ($D401 low), noise + gate ($D404 = $81), optional filter cutoff sweep down for extra effect.

references.topic: sweeping filter cutoff to enhance impact

splits.name: sound_effect_drum_kick
splits.description: Drum kick example: short noise burst followed by low-frequency tone. Sequence: set ADSR for short envelope, set initial freq high and noise+gate for a burst, after 1-2 frames switch to low frequency triangle ($D401/$D404) to simulate kick pitch drop.

references.topic: use triangle for low tone tail

splits.name: sound_effect_hand_clap_filtered_noise
splits.description: Hand clap (filtered noise) example: set master volume and filter ($D416/$D415), set resonance and route voice to filter ($D417), enable low-pass and set volume on $D418, set noise burst with short ADSR ($D405/$D406), select noise + gate ($D404 = $81).

references.topic: routing voice through filter and resonance settings

splits.name: sample_playback_digi_techniques
splits.description: Digitized sample playback on 6581 using volume-register click: code example for nybble-packed 4-bit samples played via writes to $D418 (two 4-bit samples per byte). Notes: produces 4-bit audio (16 levels), CPU intensive, conflicts with normal music (shared volume register), works well on 6581 but barely on 8580 without ~330kΩ resistor on EXT IN. Mentions advanced Mahoney 8-bit techniques.

references.topic: why 8580 requires resistor mod for digi
volume register click exploited for digi playback

splits.name: typical_instrument_patches
splits.description: Starting-point ADSR and waveform settings (patch table) for common sounds: Piano (Pulse, A=0 D=9 S=0 R=0), Organ, Violin/String, Flute, Brass, Xylophone, Bass, Synth Lead, Snare, Hi-Hat, Kick Drum. Includes notes on PWM and filter usage.

references.topic: PWM usage in Piano and Synth Lead examples
filter usage for snare and hand clap

splits.name: pinout_reference
splits.description: MOS 6581/8580 28-pin DIP pinout: CAP1A/B, CAP2A/B, /RES, PHI2, R/W, /CS, A0-A4 address lines, GND, D0-D7 data bus, POT X/Y (pins 23/24), Vcc +5V, EXT IN, AUDIO OUT, Vdd supply (+12V 6581 or +9V 8580). Notes on filter capacitor differences per chip.

references.topic: external input pin (EXT IN) and filtering
CAP values used by different revisions

splits.name: known_quirks_and_bugs
splits.description: List of SID quirks: ADSR bug (delayed retrigger), noise LFSR lockup and recovery (write TEST then waveform), write-only register readback returns bus value, 6581 filter distortion and DC offset, combined waveform differences between 6581/8580, TEST bit behavior (oscillator reset/hold), and volume-register click exploited for digi playback on 6581.

references.topic: volume click exploitation and differences across chips

splits.name: sid_register_quick_reference_card
splits.description: Concise SID register quick reference table: addresses $D400-$D41C, decimal equivalents, register names and bit layouts (Freq Lo/Hi, PW Lo/Hi, Control NPSTWRSG, Attack/Decay AAAADDDD, Sustain/Release SSSSRRRR, Filter Cutoff Lo/Hi, Resonance/Route RRRREFFF, Mode/Volume MHBL VVVV). Includes control register bit mnemonic and filter bit definitions.

references.topic: full register map and mirror range
